G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant Massachusetts precedent, this Court is authorized to modify existing custody orders upon a showing of a "material change in circumstances" and when such modification promotes the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as the issues involve the custody and well-being of a minor child residing in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Berkshire Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 209C, § 3, as the matter arises out of prior proceedings in this Court and the parties reside within its jurisdiction.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841-42 (.proposition: Massachusetts law establishes that any custody arrangement must prioritize the safety, stability, and best interests of the minor child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841-42 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that Massachusetts custody determinations are governed by the “best interests of the child” standard and elaborates that stability and continuity of a satisfactory placement are central components of that best‑interests analysis. The court emphasizes that it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to preserve an existing, adequate arrangement and warns that unnecessary disruption of the status quo increases risk of harm, thereby highlighting safety, stability, and the child’s welfare as paramount considerations in any custody order.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841-42 (.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.proposition: Massachusetts law establishes that any custody arrangement must prioritize the safety, stability, and best interests of the minor child.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for removing a child from a natural parent—parental unfitness, clear and convincing evidence, and avoiding decisions based on lifestyle disapproval—rather than laying down a general rule that any custody arrangement must prioritize safety, stability, and best interests. While it does discuss the child’s welfare and best interests in the context of state intervention, it does not articulate a broad, across-the-board requirement that all custody arrangements under Massachusetts law must prioritize safety, stability, and best interests as such. The proposition slightly overstates and reframes the case’s more specific holding on parental unfitness and state intervention.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.relevant_excerpt: “Also, parents have a natural right to the custody of their children. … However, the parents’ right to custody is not absolute, and it must yield to the welfare of the child. … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 260 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Where the Defendant’s physical limitations have rendered him unable to provide the same level of care and supervision as when the initial order was entered, a modification is necessary.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case does not discuss a defendant’s physical limitations or any deterioration in a parent’s ability to provide care due to physical incapacity. Instead, it holds that modification of custody must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the changes relied on there (relocation and a temporary order) did not justify a change in custody. The opinion therefore provides general standards for modification but does not establish that a parent’s new physical limitations necessarily require modification, as the proposition states.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Court enter an order modifying the custody arrangement to award primary physical custody to Jessica Turner, with Michael Turner receiving reasonable parenting time as appropriate given his physical condition and the best interests of Emily Turner.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition asks the court to modify custody to award primary physical custody to one parent, citing Yannas. Yannas does affirm that trial judges may award physical custody to one parent based on the child’s best interests, but its holding and analysis focus on standards for removal of children from the jurisdiction and on rejecting a presumption in favor of joint physical custody—not on standards for modifying an existing custody order due to a parent’s physical condition. Thus, it does not directly support the specific requested modification described in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child. … We reject the husband’s assertion that the law of the Commonwealth favors or should presumptively favor joint physical custody. … The matter of physical custody is appropriately left to the judge for determination unfettered by any presumption in favor of joint physical custody.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.proposition: The requested modification will ensure Emily’s welfare, safety, emotional well-being, and continuity of care while respecting the Defendant’s parenting time to the extent that it does not endanger the child or place undue responsibility upon her.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the standard for removal and modification in terms of the children’s “best interests,” but it does not articulate the specific proposition claimed. The quoted language about ensuring welfare, safety, emotional well-being, continuity of care, and respecting parenting time so long as it does not endanger the child or place undue responsibility on her does not appear in, nor is it closely paraphrased from, Mason v. Coleman. The case is about relocation with joint physical custody, not about the particular balancing formulation stated in the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below… The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The requested modification will ensure Emily’s welfare, safety, emotional well-being, and continuity of care while respecting the Defendant’s parenting time to the extent that it does not endanger the child or place undue responsibility upon her.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a requested *modification* of parenting time that will ensure a child’s welfare, safety, emotional well‑being, and continuity of care while allowing parenting time so long as it does not endanger the child or impose undue responsibility on her. Rolde v. Rolde is a divorce/custody/visitation appeal addressing initial custody and visitation determinations, not a post‑judgment modification standard, and it does not articulate the specific balancing principle described in the proposition. While it discusses the ‘best interests’ standard and limits on visitation when parents are at odds, it does not frame the rule in terms of respecting parenting time only to the extent that it does not endanger the child or place undue responsibility on the child, so it does not provide direct authority for the quoted proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’… ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

Dusoe v. Johnson, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 13,.raw_text: Dusoe v. Johnson, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 13, 17 (2007)
Dusoe v. Johnson, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 13,.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that custody modifications serve the best interests of the child above all else.
Dusoe v. Johnson, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 13,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Dusoe v. Johnson is a criminal case about failure to register as a sex offender and accosting or annoying, not a family-law or custody proceeding. It does not discuss custody, custody modification standards, or the best interests of the child, and therefore cannot be authority for the claimed proposition about Massachusetts custody law. The citation is inapposite for that purpose.
Dusoe v. Johnson, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 13,.relevant_excerpt: After a jury-waived trial, the defendant was found guilty on a complaint that he knowingly failed to register as a sex offender, G. L. c. 6, § 178H, and accosted or annoyed a person of the opposite sex, G. L. c. 272, § 53. We conclude that there was insufficient evidence to support the defendant’s convictions, and we reverse.

Custody of a Minor, 392 Mass. 728, 735 (.proposition: The Plaintiff asserts that the current custody arrangement no longer promotes Emily’s best interests due to her father’s medical condition and the resulting stresses and risks.
Custody of a Minor, 392 Mass. 728, 735 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns jurisdiction, interstate/international comity, and enforcement of a foreign custody order under the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act. It does not address modification of a custody arrangement based on a parent’s medical condition, nor does it analyze how changed parental health or related stresses affect the child’s best interests. The only discussion of “best interests” appears in the context of recognizing whether a foreign court used a comparable legal standard, not as an application to changed circumstances like a medical condition.
Custody of a Minor, 392 Mass. 728, 735 (.relevant_excerpt: "Finally, as the Appeals Court said, the foreign order must be based on a determination of the best interests of the child. This is a corollary to the requirement that the foreign substantive law must be reasonably comparable to ours. Here the Australian judge expressly recognized that standard ("welfare of the child as the paramount consideration" — Family Law Act 1975, § 64 [1] [a])... We see nothing to indicate that the Australian judge did not undertake to apply the appropriate law."

Demarco v. Demarco, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 26.raw_text: Demarco v. Demarco, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 263, 266-67 (2016)
Demarco v. Demarco, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 26.proposition: The Plaintiff emphasizes this Court’s longstanding recognition that stability, physical safety, and emotional well-being are paramount in any custody arrangement.
Demarco v. Demarco, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 26.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal case about larceny and uttering, not Demarco v. Demarco, and it does not concern custody, children’s interests, or family-law standards. It therefore does not establish or discuss any principle about stability, physical safety, or emotional well-being being paramount in custody determinations, so it cannot support the cited custody-related proposition.
Demarco v. Demarco, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 26.relevant_excerpt: In order to sustain a conviction of larceny, the Commonwealth must prove “that a defendant took the personal property of another without the right to do so, and ‘with the specific intent to deprive the other of the property permanently.’ … The defendant contends that the Commonwealth failed to present sufficient evidence to prove his specific intent to commit larceny. We disagree.”

Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 605-0.proposition: The Plaintiff emphasizes this Court’s longstanding recognition that stability, physical safety, and emotional well-being are paramount in any custody arrangement.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 605-0.support_reasoning: The decision clearly recognizes that custody determinations must be based on the best interests of the child and emphasizes the need for accurate, fair fact-finding, but it does not expressly frame the governing standard in terms of ‘stability, physical safety, and emotional well-being’ as paramount. Instead, it focuses on procedural fairness (right to cross‑examine a guardian ad litem) and briefly restates the traditional ‘best interests of the child’ principle, citing an earlier case (Hersey v. Hersey) for that standard. Thus, it only indirectly and generally relates to the proposition and does not specifically articulate the three factors claimed by the plaintiff.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598, 605-0.relevant_excerpt: “There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). … In a custody proceeding, a judge makes a determination as to what is in the best interests of the child on the basis of facts presented at trial as well as facts gathered by the court-appointed investigators. The need for accurate, objective information is of foremost importance in this process.”
